svg:text.svg:tspan: The Tempipettes and MacBurette — Shakespeare for chemists...
It’s no good throwing chemicals around willy nilly and calling it an experiment. To make sure your results are
reproducible, so can be trusted by other scientists, you have to make sure all your measurements are accurate.
You May Have to Measure the for a Change
1)You should use a to experiments. These measure to the nearest so are .
2)Always make sure you and the stopwatch at exactly the right time. For example, if you’re
investigating the rate of an experiment, you should start timing at the you mix the
reagents and start the reaction. If you’re measuring the time taken for a precipitate to form,
you should watch the reaction like a hawk so you can timing the moment it goes cloudy.
Be Careful When You or Substances
1)There are lots of hazards in chemistry experiments, so you start any experiment,
you should read any to do with your method or the chemicals you’re using.
The substances used in chemical reactions are often . For example, they might catch fire
easily (they’re flammable), or they might irritate or burn your skin if you come into contact with them.
Whenever you’re doing an experiment, you should wear a , and .
Always be careful that the chemicals you’re using aren’t flammable before you go lighting
any Bunsen burners, and make sure you’re working in an area that’s .
If you’re doing an experiment that might produce nasty (such as chlorine), you should carry out
the experiment in a so that the gas can’t escape out into the room you’re working in.
Never directly touch any chemicals (even if you’re wearing gloves). Use a to transfer
between containers. Carefully liquids between different containers, using a to avoid spillages.
Be careful when you’re chemicals, as a reaction might occur. If you’re a liquid, add the
to the (not the other way around) or the mixture could get very .
You need to be able to decide the best method for measuring pH, depending on what your experiment is.
1) are dyes that depending on whether they’re in an or an .
ou use them by adding a couple of drops of the indicator to the solution you’re interested in.
They’re useful for titration reactions, when you want to find the point at which a solution is neutralised.
2) is a of indicators that changes colour as pH changes. It doesn’t
show a colour change. It’s useful for the pH of a solution based on its colour.
Indicators can be soaked into and strips of this paper
can be used for testing pH
. If you use a dropping pipette to
spot a small amount of a solution onto some indicator paper,
it will depending on the pH of the solution.
Indicator paper is useful when you want to change the
colour of of the substance, or if the substance is coloured so might the colour
ou can also hold a piece of in a to test its pH.
5) are attached to pH meters which have a that gives a
value for the pH of a solution. They’re used to give an of pH.
Measure to Find Out How or a Solution Is
to the pH based on its colour.
You can use a to measure the temperature of a substance:
1)Make sure the of your thermometer is in any mixture you’re measuring.
2)If you’re taking an initial reading, you should wait for the temperature to first.
Read your measurement off the on a thermometer at to make sure it’s correct.
